Re-implementing the Discover API using Sodium `Stream` and `Cell` was almost trivial and it gets rid of all the complexity with managing and notifying subscriptions. Huge win in reducing the amount of code in the discovery service. I should be able to maintain the current Client API and implement it using the Sodium API and eventually transition all clients to directly using the Sodium API.
Fixed by #316

If we add a Sodium events API to the Memory Allocator for events like `RamAvailable<number>` we can have the task selector subscribe to this `Stream` for knowing when to try and spawn more jobs.

We can also add events from the current messages the task selector receives, like for when new targets appear (derived from the Discover API), when a target changes readiness level (up or down) etc.

Instead of just wrapping the module as a Service with a message protocol, we could expand the scope to actually do target prioritization/ranking, separate from the actual task spawning of the task selector. It would depend on the target events from the Discovery service, augment them with the expect value for hacking with current RAM and then publish a sorted list according to maximum expected value per RAM second.

Open question is on how to deal with killing jobs to reclaim memory.

Experiment with "zero-delay" shotgun batching
I read old resources on implementing batch hacking. The current advice is to implement a shotgun batcher with zero delays between batches and just spawn as many batches as possible against the best target.

We should definitely try this strategy along with more precise timing calculation by calculating the ending time relative to `performance.now` and letting each spawned h/g/w helper script calculate the amount of additional time needed to end at the goal time (as described in #211).

Change startup to be more modular and based on Sodium Streams
Always start the core services like memory, port, launcher and reset info (replace source-file service).

Other services should be started on-demand by registering a script launch command. These script launching commands should include the script name, optional launch options, and a set of source file level dependencies. Or, perhaps we could write another script scanner function like the dependency gatherer to determine which NS APIs the script uses and thus what source files (or levels) it requires.

Actually, we want to be able to register multiple scripts, or perhaps the same script with different arguments and dynamic RAM settings to turn off usage of any features which aren't available.

This will really open the door to writing scripts that take advantage of APIs from different bitnodes.

The only other problem is how to name them. Currently most of the restricted APIs are in their own folders, but having conceptual folders that focus on solving a mechanic like hacking probably make more sense.

Sodium based message protocol
Wild half-asleep idea for how to structure a buffering protocol using Sodium `Stream` and `Cell`. Sending a message is sending to a published Sodium `Stream` somehow (`StreamSink`?). This `Stream` accumulates into a `Cell<Immutable.List<Message>>`.

The "server" daemon drains the buffer via sending an event that snapshots the message `Cell`, and updates the Cell to a new empty list. This event will "carry" the current buffer of messages to the listener in the server for it to process.

For performance we could treat this as a single abstraction implemented by two cooperating cells, like the amortized fast queue implementation done with two stacks (head and tail). When the head stack is empty, you flip the tail stack over into the head stack. In our case, using immutable-js persistent data structures we can implement the tail with an `Immutable.List`, and the tail is a `Immutable.Seq` over the previous tail. This could be inefficient if it's one message at a time, maybe? Need to benchmark or something?

This would allow for sending messages to a service before it is started, similar to how we can with `NetscriptPort`s.

Responses can be achieved by including a promise resolving function in the message.

Implement a hashed timing wheel (like Tokio) for precise timers
Add an API that allows precise timing of events by returning Promises that resolve when that timer has elapsed.

Internally, we can have 1 task running a timing tick that moves forward a hashed timing wheel like Tokio has implemented.

We can use a combination of conservative sleep timers, running when the browser has time for it, and wake-ups when new timers are registered to keep the performance impact of this API low.
A precise timer like this should make it much easier to implement a JIT batcher.

Sodium ApiCell caches data for too long
Since the `Cell` essentially caches data in memory indefinitely, when we do things like install augmentations, soft reset or finish a Bitnode these caches will become out of date. Currently, the start script is failing because the Discovery service values are cached and the cache is never cleared.

We can add a method to clear this cached value, and we can clear the cache when the provider script starts, however this feels a bit like going in the wrong direction.

Another possibility might be to create a Sodium proxy for the NS API. These wrappers could send events to public Streams. The tricky thing about this is that it means that every script should probably be using this wrapper, that means that a _lot_ of different streams are going to be connecting to these public APIs.

It would be much better to try to install a hook into the game internals in the appropriate spot to emit an event for the appropriate moments.

Create a Sodium NS proxy API
It might be useful to create a Sodium proxy for parts of the NS API. These wrappers could send events to public `ApiStream`s. The tricky thing about this is that it means that every script should probably be using this wrapper, that means that a lot of different streams are going to be connecting to these public APIs.

It would be much better to try to install a hook into the game internals in the appropriate spot to emit an event for the appropriate moments.

Some useful events I can think of:

- Bitnode Start
- Soft reset
- Augmentations installed
- Bitnode reset

Rewrite Port Allocator service in Sodium
The Port Allocator process actually doesn't consult the Netscript API at all. We can probably make it independent of the starter script by implementing purely in Sodium.

The "service" aspect of it would then be basically just the UI.

The only question about implementing it is if we can make a "response" for the allocation in a reasonable way. I'm not sure if the Sodium API has a "listen once" method. We want to ensure that if multiple clients request a port number they will receive unique responses.

Remote terminal print facade

This is a critical piece of letting scripts print to our custom terminal.

Config Freeze
Switching to a new Bitburner app instance or browser means that I lose the LocalStorage configs I've tuned. Trying to diff the config and copy it over is silly, so it would be nice if there was a facility to save the current config as a file, and then reload it in a new browser. Since the file will be saved as part of the Bitburner save export this would allow nicely transferring to the new machine.

It also might be useful to have a facility for updating the default values in the actual Config definitions because if I've left a config alone for very long that's probably what I want it to be in general.

You missed invite notification
When user activates app, it should check - providing that the system is not offline - if user received since last moment when he was using the app an invitation, which he didn't accepted. Then popup should be shown saying you received an invitation while you were off  and it should offer to choices: see invites or close. If user chooses see invites, then pending invites activity should be open. If close, the popup should just close.
Remember to translate strings to all supported languages in strings.

Refresh Wins
Consider scenario:
1. user A is on mobile/app/src/main/java/piotr_gorczynski/soccer2/FriendsListActivity.java
2. he invites another user, lets say B for a game and he is redirected to WaitingActivity
3. The game is accepted and he enters gameActivity
4. Suppose USer A wins
5. User is redirected back to screen FriendsListActivity.java
6. The infromation about that inite was sent from user A to B is refreshed on the screen but infromation that user A won the game is not refreshed

INvitations list
When mobile/app/src/main/java/piotr_gorczynski/soccer2/InvitationsActivity.java is opened, it does not show all invitations, only part of them.

SO i want to have explicitely paginated list, which will show button "Load more" or osmething, that will enalbe loading the remaining invitations.|

Remeber taht we should have already "Load more" string and it should be translated to all supported languages.

Separate field margin for horizontal and vertical
IN mobile/app/src/main/res/values/constants.xml there is <fraction name="flFieldMargin">15%</fraction> which is used to calculate margin while drawing field.

This margin is used foth for X axis and Y axis

I want to have two different values now

flFieldMarginY of 15%
flFieldMarginX of 5%

now while drawing field the distance of to and bootom filed should be caluslated using flFieldMarginY 
the distance between ledt and right field should be calculated using flFieldMarginX 

the flFieldMargin can be removed

Bootstrap Script Bug
User reported an error after setting up with Bootstrap script in Steam 2.8.1

> Cannot calculate RAM usage of start.js. Reason: Invalid module: "services/client/memory_tag". Base module: "start.js".

Fix bootstrap generation
There are currently several issues with the bootstrap script:

Build doesn't capture nested folders
It looks like the way I generate the build zip file only handles one level of folders, so nested folders aren't included.

Specifically, this line from the `build.yml` workflow:

```
- name: Package output
if: github.ref_type == 'tag'
run: zip ${{ env.ARTIFACT_FILE }} dist/**/*.js dist/*.js
```

This should be changed to make zip capture everything in `dist/` recursively.

Bootstrap file includes paths that have been deleted
Currently the bootstrap script is generated during build. The latest run of the bootstrap has entries for files that 404 when fetching from github.

Specifically, these files:

- `buy-hacknet.js`
- `jest-shim.js`
- `batch/lib.js`
- `batch/leak-check.js`
- `batch/worker.js`

These look like files that have been deleted or moved, and `jest-shim.js` just shouldn't be included at all.

Using an old bootstrap.js after a new release is almost guaranteed to fail
There's a mismatch in the bootstrap system where we create a frozen snapshot of the list of files in a given release, but then we pull files from the `latest-files` branch. If a new release is created between the time someone downloads the bootstrap file and when they run it, this will almost certainly result in downloading an incomplete version of the newest release, instead of a complete version of the one they tried to download.

Improve bootstrap UX
Currently, because the bootstrap uses `ns.wget` it is extremely slow and it takes a while to complete, with no visual feedback for the user. We should at least improve the experience by displaying some information.

- [ ] Console message when starting and finishing bootstrap
- [ ] Open tail window and display a progress bar of total files downloaded
- [ ] Add some cute ASCII art or something to keep them entertained maybe?

Loading screen
When game loads 1st time it takes up to 5 seconds before menuactivity is shown.

service account
The gcp\cloud-build\grant_vertex_ai_user_to_appengine_sa.yaml grants credentials to appengine_sa="${project_id}@appspot.gserviceaccount.com" (effectively it was reolved to 
soccer-dev-1744877837@appspot.gserviceaccount.com

but the way the gcp\cloud-build\deploy_check_nickname.yaml deploys function causes, that i found that the function is using  491861032786-compute@developer.gserviceaccount.com 


in order to get this name i tested and in gcli this works:

admin_@cloudshell:~ (soccer-dev-1744877837)$ gcloud run services describe checknickname     --region us-central1     --format 'value(spec.template.spec.serviceAccountName)'
491861032786-compute@developer.gserviceaccount.com
admin_@cloudshell:~ (soccer-dev-1744877837)$ 

so i suggest  in grant_vertex_ai_user_to_appengine_sa.yaml
you add logic to get this name service account name and grants it the proer role

roles/serviceusage.serviceUsageConsumer
modify gcp\cloud-build\grant_vertex_ai_user_to_appengine_sa.yaml to grant role roles/serviceusage.serviceUsageConsumer to this service account
